2020 01:00:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8a130d9e9fe40019009e80?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5620ed90c30832ec6822367777436687","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn98@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-13-740_d043362bc9fe4316.webp","destWidth":1482,"destHeight":1112,"sourceBytes":45484,"destBytes":45484,"author":"insider@insider.com (Christine Kopaczewski,Grace Eliza Goodwin)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f747de10ab50d00184ad368?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn31@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-25-887_396bec180900d9df.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f8a0dbf9e9fe40019009e6e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn19@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-19-112_cbf2e4f2126d203e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f8a0cff9e9fe40019009e6c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn52@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-28-080_052a63d48707557e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51cc8569b5548df4d16e8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn67@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-16-008_d10bd8f68a2e9fdc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51cf46b5265452f420e47?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn36@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-23-705_2855eb0cf59317b1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51d3e6b5265452f420e4b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn100@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-25-807_17dff2a6cea686c6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51d7cc6cc50614b3a7939?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn91@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-27-725_0d506fc943bdd5fd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51d92c6cc5063da7f8be2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn59@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-27-512_ed5dd2f07b043b62.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51dcac6cc506cb179b1a6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn87@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-22-079_971ca8add239ec4d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51ddf16c9583d9a55f7b5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn68@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-26-842_e7bfa9f1cc375414.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ca51e0ac6cc50636b63f4f9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn47@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-806_773b2ae048147118.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fqp7h6RXoNs:97Assno00o4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn59@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-23-919_d9bfa21e6847cbfc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fqp7h6RXoNs:97Assno00o4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn39@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-19-244_b8bca9fc8744095d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fqp7h6RXoNs:97Assno00o4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn59@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-23-377_4d2b2a3ca744b600.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/fqp7h6RXoNs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn7@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-19-792_6f29bb6666a62569.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799675},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"I stepped down as CEO of my company after battling fertility issues, brain cancer, and depression. I want other founders and CEOs to know that sometimes letting go is the best option.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/circleup-ceo-ryan-caldbeck-candid-stepping-down-right-decision-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89f127d260780019341ee6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ryan Caldbeck Headshot\" height=\"370\" width=\"494\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ryan Caldbeck.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ryan Caldbeck</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Ryan Caldbeck recently stepped down as the CEO of CircleUp after leading the fintech company for almost nine years.</li>\n<li>Caldbeck was raising funding and running a startup while hiding his personal battle with fertility and brain cancer, which culminated into a dark period of mental health problems and extreme exhaustion.</li>\n<li>\"For years I did a poor job of communicating the depth of my stress and exhaustion, a problem only compounded by the fact that, at times, I wasn't even sure of my own feelings,\" he said.&#160;</li>\n<li>After 12 months of transitioning into his new role as executive chairman, Caldbeck now shares a candid, vulnerable account of his journey to inspire other entrepreneurs to confront their feelings and ask for help.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p id=\"c0e2\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">On October 13, 2020 I stepped down as CEO of CircleUp, the company I started in 2011 with my cofounder, Rory Eakin.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Leaving the best job I ever had — at the company I helped to create — was difficult and confusing. I wish I had found other stories about how the transition actually went and what it felt like. But I found surprisingly few first-hand accounts from founders or CEOs transitioning from their initial role, and even fewer that shared their full, authentic story of what really happened when they left and how they truly felt about the process.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">With limited precedent to guide me, I found the process extremely hard to manage, both logistically and emotionally.</p><p id=\"f515\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">That's why I'm writing this blog. I'm sure I didn't do everything right in executing my transition, but that isn't the point. I'm not here to share a playbook — I don't think one exists. I want to share my experiences and vulnerabilities with full candor in the hope that other founders can have a resource that I lacked; that they can learn from my experience and feel less lonely than I have through this process. I also hope this piece can help build greater empathy and understanding among the investors, teams, and families that have backed, supported, and lived with founders whose struggles might at first seem opaque or impenetrable but are, in essence, deeply human.</p><h2 id=\"5c60\"><strong>Why I chose to step down as CEO of CircleUp</strong></h2><p id=\"7d08\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Over the past year, when I began telling team members, investors, LPs, and other stakeholders about my transition, their first question was, inevitably, \"Why?\" I typically explained that the average founder/CEO of a startup is in the seat for less than five years; I had been with CircleUp for nine, and I was exhausted. But there was so much more to it than that.</p><p id=\"1938\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I don't remember the first time I told our board that I was exhausted and needed to step down as CEO. I imagine it was around 2016 or 2017, a period defined by stressful business decisions and physical and mental health issues. I later realized that the board interpreted my complaints as \"typical founder/CEO exhaustion.\" I blame myself for that lack of clarity.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">For years I did a poor job of communicating the depth of my stress and exhaustion, a problem only compounded by the fact that, at times, I wasn't even sure of my own feelings. There were stretches of time where I felt horrible — lonely; terrified; depressed. Depression exacerbates exhaustion. But I tried to put on a brave face to make sure the board felt comfortable.</p><h2>There were also occasional periods where I felt joy, which complicated matters even more.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">The highs kept me going even though I knew the downs were unhealthy and untenable. It was hard for me to measure how much of my pain was because I had young kids at home, the result of specific business challenges or a classic case of founder/CEO exhaustion. What is normal? There was no way to answer that other than to go by my own feelings. From 2011–17, my exhaustion felt \"normal.\" Starting in 2017, it no longer did. I no longer felt like a missionary, I felt like a mercenary.</p><p id=\"da85\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">The root of these negative feelings can be boiled down to roughly an 18-month period from mid-2016 through 2017. During that time, we&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/ryan_caldbeck/status/1118288136918847488\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">pivoted CircleUp</a> away from the original marketplace. We also had to go through a round of layoffs, the first I'd ever had to navigate as a CEO. They were necessary, but they were brutal. The people we let go had joined because they believed in our product and mission. They had done nothing wrong, yet suddenly there was no longer a place for them.</p><h2>I remember letting go of someone I had known since college.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">She turned to me and said, \"I took this job over something that paid more, and now what should I do?\" These agonizing decisions kept me up at night for weeks, and I know it was much harder on those affected.</p><p id=\"2329\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Then we raised our&#160;<a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexkonrad/2017/10/31/circleup-fund-brings-moneyball-to-consumer-brands/#2ec9fa142a82\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">first institutional VC fund</a> (just one of the ways in which we monetize our tech). If you have friends in venture and it looks like a cushy job, see if they've raised a first-time fund. It's not as hard as being a CEO, but it is … not cushy. I was doing both — running a technology company while meeting with hundreds of institutional LPs around the world to raise a first-time VC fund.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">After the pivot, after the layoffs and after raising that $125 million fund, we raised a meaningful round for the parent company from Temasek and TPG. I don't know how we raised a big round from world-class investors right after a pivot, but we got it done.</p><h2 id=\"8294\">Simultaneously, we were forced to deal with a board member who was beyond counterproductive.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">After we bought him out fully in 2019, I sent <a href=\"https://docs.google.com/document/d/17tEc9ETL4tjfTmNbpwJJ5OSx1c4j10ZBgeYXWGzO30Y/edit?usp=sharing\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">this feedback email</a>&#160;detailing the ways in which he had disrupted our board and company. Dealing with this issue was one of the loneliest times I faced as a CEO. To be clear, this email is unlike anything I've sent in my life, and I've thought long and hard about the decision to share it. I'm not doing so to disparage the individual in question; the only objective is to help others who might find themselves in a similar situation. (Nothing has been removed, including typos, from the email except for names.)</p><p id=\"a09e\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">That group of professional challenges was more difficult than anything else I've faced in my career. At the time, I told a teammate that it felt like I was playing seven-dimensional chess because of the complexity of the negotiations combined with so many conflicting challenges at work.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">What she didn't know — and what most people didn't know — is that during that same 18-month window, I was also juggling personal challenges that were far more stressful than the hurdles at work.</p><h2 id=\"455d\">It started with absolutely brutal fertility issues that my wife and I went through, beginning in 2016.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">As far back as college, I've made hard decisions with the goal of building a great family. That emphasis has impacted everything from which jobs I've pursued to what foods I've eaten — even before I was married. So you can imagine how those fertility issues impacted me and my wife, Kim. We met with five or six of the best fertility clinics in the country. There were so many tests. Eventually, we were blessed with our second child, but it was an extremely painful and isolating process.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">One of those tests revealed unexpected, terrifying information. I was diagnosed with cancer.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I only remember a pair of words from the first conversation with my doctor: \"two tumors.\" I struggled to process it at first. I barely drink, have never smoked or done drugs and work out five times a week.</p><h2>How could I have cancer? The doctor must not have been speaking clearly.</h2><p id=\"b203\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">But he was. Still in shock, and with my hands shaking out of fear, I took the elevator to another floor for immediate tests — before I could even break the news to my wife. Slowly, reality began to sink in and the enormity of the word \"malignant\" hit me in full force.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I remember crying to the nurse as she drew blood. Then I walked outside the UCSF hospital, hid behind a concrete pillar, and finally called my wife. I was losing control, and while she tried to be strong, I could hear the fear in her voice. I'd never really heard her scared before, and I felt helpless being unable to do anything to change the situation.</p><p id=\"d78f\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Two days later, I flew to a work conference in Anaheim, CA, while also trying to schedule further tests and treatment. In a 30-minute Uber ride, I told my story multiple times over the phone to multiple administrators at multiple hospitals (for reasons that aren't relevant to this blog post, my medical case was uniquely and extremely complex).</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I remember no one said, \"I'm sorry\" — they just processed the logistics with an icy, clinical precision that is probably required for someone to work in a cancer center. Finally I lost it, shouting, \"Why aren't you just saying 'I'm sorry' right now?\" It wasn't fair to them, and I'm not proud of it, but I cracked.</p><h2>For the next several months, my emotions would sometimes pour out in a tidal wave of tears and yelling.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Anger, frustration, fear, confusion — there were so many feelings to contend with. Throughout the entire Uber ride, my driver hadn't said a word. But as we pulled up to the hotel and I climbed out, he opened his door, stood up and gave me a hug. He then said: \"Hey, I just want you to know I had the same type of cancer. I'm so sorry.\"</p><p id=\"117d\">The cancer diagnosis became even tougher to deal with because I mistakenly believed I shouldn't discuss it with others. CircleUp had just gone through our pivot and we were in the middle of raising that first fund and the parent company round. At the time, I worried that the team would use my diagnosis as an excuse to throw in the towel, that my health would become a distraction, cause the company to fail and make things that much worse.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I told the board and my cofounder about my diagnosis, but no one else at the company knew. I even hid the information from all but a few friends, fearing that word might get out. In retrospect, I think I would have brought our company closer together by being vulnerable and authentic, and I certainly wouldn't have felt as lonely.</p><h2 id=\"0e8e\">I had a successful operation.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Since then, I have undergone regular testing several times a year. To this day, I cry every time I go to the cancer center at Stanford. In hindsight I should have seen a psychologist to process what I was going through — the emotional toll was far worse for me than the physical.</p><p id=\"d079\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Dealing with the fertility problem, cancer, and issues at work all at once was the hardest challenge of my life. I couldn't sleep, couldn't relax, and was constantly on edge. For weeks at a time I had blurred vision. The combination of personal and professional stress was far beyond what I could handle. I hadn't had a headache in 20-plus years and now I couldn't go through a full day without experiencing crippling pain in my head.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">The doctors did two MRIs on my brain to see if the cancer had spread there. After the first MRI, they initially thought it had. After the second they said: \"Eleven doctors have looked at this and we have determined it is not cancer.\" I assure you that wasn't as comforting as it may now sound as it begs the question, \"Why did you need eleven?\"</p><h2 id=\"9ef7\">A few weeks later, I started peeing blood, repeatedly.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">After more tests, the doctors assured me that this latest symptom was also unrelated to my cancer. These symptoms were one-in-a-million flukes. I told my cancer doctor, \"I like data. That's a lot of one-in-a-million flukes.\" I now had a six-month-old boy at home, a relentless fear of whether the doctors might have missed something and an ongoing slew of professional challenges to face.</p><p id=\"e5a7\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">By the end of 2017, I was completely worn out. Then, suddenly, the major professional challenges were done.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">We got the round done for CircleUp. We raised the fund. The pivot was behind us. My personal obstacles were under better control and we now had an infant boy along with our daughter, who was three at the time. A great board member, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/dan-ciporin-198a4/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Dan</a>, called me to say, \"Ryan, I've never in my career seen a CEO as worn out as you. Please, you need to take a sabbatical — at least six weeks.\" He, and other board members, tried so hard to do the right thing and convince me to take care of myself.</p><h2>But after a lifetime of gritting things out, I told myself I didn't need to take a break.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I think an element of my reaction is what Jerry Colonna calls \"false grit\" in \"<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Reboot-Leadership-Art-Growing-Up/dp/0062749536/ref=asc_df_0062749536/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=343203979134&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=10912074687442815466&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9031915&hvtargid=pla-771288719468&psc=1&tag=&ref=&adgrpid=69360436752&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvadid=343203979134&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=10912074687442815466&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9031915&hvtargid=pla-77128871946874687442815466&#38;hvqmt=&#38;hvdev=c&#38;hvdvcmdl=&#38;hvlocint=&#38;hvlocphy=9031915&#38;hvtargid=pla-771288719468\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Reboot</a>.\"</p><p id=\"fa7b\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">But it was hard to turn away from persistence when it has been so crucial to any success I've achieved. Grit (along with undeniable privilege) helped get me to where I am even though I have never been the smartest, tallest, or most skilled person in the room.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">When Dan asked me to step back — even just temporarily — I thought about how I had gritted out making the basketball team as a walk-on at Duke just months after double knee surgery and my doctor saying I needed to give up basketball. I thought about how I gritted out getting into business school and securing a job in private equity after being denied by the first 70-plus PE firms I reached out to (even offering my services for free). I thought about what I had said to Rory in 2011 when we were discussing the possibility of launching CircleUp: \"I need you to know that I never give up.\"</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Persistence was my superpower. But now I've now come to understand that persistence is a double-edged sword and my decision not to take a break to not take more off my plate hurt me my family and the company.</p><h2>That was the biggest mistake of my career.</h2><p id=\"2ca6\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">From there, my exhaustion only grew. The job itself was nowhere near as difficult as it had been in the past, but depression and burnout can make even small challenges feel like a big deal. Problems seemed to stack one on top of the other. Moments of happiness were fleeting. A few teammates tried to help me focus only on work that brought me joy, but I failed at that task. I absorbed very little pleasure from our wins, and quite a bit of pain from our losses.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I remember a top VC, who was not one of our investors, posted something very positive about me and CircleUp online. I read it on my phone and immediately said, \"Damnit!\" to my wife. I explained that he couldn't possibly know enough to mean these positive things, and his comments only made me wish that he genuinely did.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I had gotten to a place where I only focused on the losses and couldn't accept positive things.</p><h2 id=\"f8fa\">I've eventually realized that for far too long, I wasn't clear — with myself or others — about what I wanted or needed.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">At times I thought I was sending up big red flares that I couldn't sustain my pace, but others were just seeing the normal ups and downs of a founder. I believe hundreds of founders have their own version of this story, but it is rarely told. I hope that my candor helps others to feel more comfortable than I did asking for help and more willing than I was to confront feelings of loneliness and weakening stamina before they reach a breaking point.</p><p id=\"0c80\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">For me, that happened in the fall of 2019. There was no final straw at work; frankly the company was doing better than it ever had and my job was actually easier than it ever had been. It didn't matter: I could only feel pain.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Finally, my daughter looked at me and said, \"Daddy, why do you always look so sad?\" She was five.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">It was the push I needed to change.</p><h2 id=\"98b6\"><strong>Making the transition</strong></h2><p id=\"4bc2\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">In October 2019 I told the board that I planned to transition out as CEO. I prepped for the conversation with my management coach and some CEO friends, but I was still terrified of the potential reaction. I&#160;<a href=\"https://docs.google.com/document/d/106LwbMxyPqGLwiqcpW4DcSrFVgApwKGbZXGvUjGsTCI/edit?usp=sharing\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">then followed up with this email</a>&#160;(included here with their permission). I have changed nothing in the note (not even a typo) other than redacting email addresses. Once again, I'm not sharing this information because I think it was the perfect way to handle the situation, but so others might be able to learn from my experience. I certainly wish I'd had examples to lean on.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">The board wasn't happy when I sent that email.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I don't blame them. I knew it would be a difficult transition for CircleUp, but I also believed it was the right move for the company as much as it was the right move for me. They tried to convince me to stay, but I made it clear that wasn't an option, that this wasn't about any issue other than my mental wellbeing.</p><p id=\"bb1a\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">After several discussions, the board became aligned with my decision but felt I wouldn't be able to transition within 12 months. Believing that to attract a great CEO we would need more than two years of runway, the board wanted us to raise a round. In their minds, we wouldn't be able to hire a new CEO until that was done, and doing both simultaneously would be impossible to get done in less than a year. I disagreed: Even though I knew how difficult it would be to accomplish both tasks at once, I was confident it could be done.</p><h2 id=\"3ba4\">Raising a round and hiring a replacement in parallel was emotionally draining, in part because I had to show passion and excitement even though I was personally exhausted.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I wasn't misleading them about my belief in the business or my intentions going forward, but I was trying to mask the depression I felt. Who wants to invest in an unhappy CEO? For investors, vulnerability or burnout is often conflated with risk.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">So I felt I had no choice but to be a source of energy for potential stakeholders even though I barely had enough energy for myself. Have you ever had to put on a good face when guests come over, even though you're in a horrible mood? It felt like that, with no end of dinner in sight and with much higher stakes than awkward small talk. And, for good measure, we had to get all of this done during a global pandemic.</p><p id=\"32ed\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Still, in less than a year we raised a big round (not announced) on terms both we and the board were happy with. We hired a fantastic president,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/nick-talwar-238333/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Nick Talwar</a>, who became CEO on October 13, the day I became Executive Chairman. While I know this is the right decision, there are huge parts of the job I deeply love and will miss.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">When it was time for me to sign Nick's offer letter, I stared at my computer screen for 35 minutes. My wife came in and I cried with her. She took this picture.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89e864d260780019341ea6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ryan Caldbeck\" height=\"1050\" width=\"1400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Caldbeck signing the offer letter.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kim Caldbeck</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>More than a few people have asked me what comes next.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">First, I am transferring to a full-time executive chairman role at CircleUp. I'm still here, just with far less stress. I've worked on this transition for a while with my management coach, <a href=\"https://www.edbatista.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Ed Batista</a>. I've also talked with countless CEOs (including my <a href=\"https://leadersintech.org/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">LIT group</a>), friends, and advisors.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">One of the better books I've read is \"<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Transitions-Making-Changes-Revised-Anniversary/dp/073820904X\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Transitions\" by William Bridges</a>. In it, he talks about becoming comfortable with living in the \"nothingness\" and saying, \"I don't know\" when asked, \"What's next?\" A successful and healthy transition requires one to live in the nothingness between the end of one period and the beginning of another. I need to come to terms with the end of my time as CEO, though I will still be here at CircleUp. Eventually I won't be. I don't know when that day will come. And if you ask me what's after that, my answer is … I don't know.</p><p id=\"4fe5\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Now that I have a chance to reflect, my feelings are complicated. I am relieved that I'm getting help in the form of a new CEO. I feel sad that my journey as CEO of CircleUp has come to an end. I feel fear in that I don't know what's next, even though I believe it's healthy for me not to know. I feel nervous about how people will interpret this transition and what narrative they will tell themselves (and others). When I've talked about my journey in the past, I've had similar concerns, but these ones are greater. I feel frustrated that there are things I could have and should have done differently. I feel insecure about my answer of \"I don't know\" when asked what I'll do next — that it will be viewed as inadequate. I worry about whether I will ever do anything again that I feel as passionate about: being the founder and CEO of CircleUp is the greatest job I've ever had.</p><h2 id=\"29dc\">I feel unsure about how others will react. In venture, doubt isn't respected.</h2><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I am confident some, especially in VC, will inevitably view my story as a lack of grit. Would their perception of me be better if, instead of helping CircleUp pivot and leaving three years later, the company had failed in 2017? Maybe my experience means some VCs will not fund me again. Maybe it means I now have more empathy for entrepreneurs. Could I have stuck it out if not for the personal issues? I think so, but I can't know the answer to that any more than I can know how people will react to this account.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">My only hope is that it might help other founders feel less alone.</p><p id=\"5b25\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Again, everyone has their things. I'm trying to share my experience — the full and honest version — so that you hopefully don't feel as lonely on your journey. I want you to know that there are other founders/CEOs who feel that they have no choice but to \"tough it out\" in front of the teams, customers, or investors, despite what's going on at home.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">For me a perfect storm of personal problems unhappily coincided with some of the most critical business decisions and processes possible. Is that just bad luck? I don't think so. Lots of people have to deal with many things happening at once. If you are in this seat for long enough, it will happen to you. But if there's any way to make these things worse it's to ignore the warning signs. I could have made it through for longer had I searched for help sooner — that isn't bad luck, it was me choosing not to lean on a broader team to get through the hardest periods.</p><p id=\"4173\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">Primarily, I feel so much pride in what the team has accomplished and have absolute confidence in the company's bright future. CircleUp has built transformational&#160;<a href=\"https://circleup.com/helio/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">tech</a>&#160;and the team has helped hundreds of entrepreneurs thrive by giving them the capital and resources they need. CircleUp now boasts a new CEO with an incredibly relevant background and skill set and fresh legs to take the company to greater heights. I feel excited<a href=\"https://medium.com/@ryancaldbeck/circleups-mission-vision-strategy-5cfc0a4540a4\" rel=\"noopener\">&#160;about our roadmap</a>. I think the investment to build our technology platform, Helio, has set us up to create extraordinary impact and I feel appreciative of the team members that have been here since our first engineer,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/brycedrennan/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Bryce</a>, took a bet on us in 2011.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I feel thankful for the partnership that <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/matthewchristensen41/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Matt</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrewweissman/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Andy</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/dan-ciporin-198a4/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">Dan</a>, and other advisors and investors have given to CircleUp, and to me personally, for years. I truly feel lucky for their help in steering the ship, particularly through difficult times, with skill, vision, patience, and resolve. I know I am privileged to be in a demographic, time, and geography that makes starting something this audacious feel possible. I feel fortunate to have had the chance to start CircleUp with such a fantastic cofounder, someone who placed our shared values and the Company's mission above personal glory. I cannot fully express how much I trust Rory and how valuable that trust has been both to me and to the business as a whole.</p><p data-selectable-paragraph=\"\"></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89e9b59e9fe40019009d80?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ryan caldbeck\" height=\"1050\" width=\"1400\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Caldbeck and his daughter.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ryan Caldbeck</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p id=\"0c21\" data-selectable-paragraph=\"\">I feel appreciative of my family and parents for helping me dream and also pushing me to see that I needed to make changes to be happy. And finally, I am thankful for a wife who encouraged me to follow my dream in 2011 and supported me throughout. In the best of times and the worst of times, she has only ever used CircleUp as a positive example for our (now) three kids — to chase their dreams. And most of all I feel proud of my daughter for speaking her mind.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ryancaldbeck/\">Ryan Caldbeck</a> is the founder and Executive Chairman of CircleUp, an investment platform powered by technology. Ryan served as CEO from 2012 through 2020. He founded <a href=\"https://www.circleup.com/\">CircleUp</a> after seven years as an investor with consumer product and retail-focused private equity firms TSG Consumer Partners and Encore Consumer Capital. </em><em>Ryan received his MBA from Stanford and a dual BA from Duke. He was named a \"Titan of Retail\" by Bloomberg, won the 2013 40 Under 40 M&#38;A Advisor Recognition Award, and was a 2014 40 Under 40 San Francisco Business Times Honoree.</em></p><div height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 16 Oct 2020 20:49:19 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f89f11d9e9fe40019009dba?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a0735bce874f7af6e89df9ec43db3e8f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn97@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-14-240_48ccb445a7290d4e.webp","destWidth":494,"destHeight":370,"sourceBytes":13272,"destBytes":13272,"author":"insider@insider.com (Ryan Caldbeck)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89f127d260780019341ee6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn60@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-21-823_60666990597fccb7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89e864d260780019341ea6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn43@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-19-261_b1a4d34d7db73b27.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89e9b59e9fe40019009d80?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn28@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-24-624_0120c7a7863a5f0a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=N28YPNcMEm8:awA62LjSCuQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn99@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-26-317_17646b18633f64f9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=N28YPNcMEm8:awA62LjSCuQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn4@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-22-805_e537f9dfb2c4770a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=N28YPNcMEm8:awA62LjSCuQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn3@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-20-022_8ea47dd1c62f39b2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/N28YPNcMEm8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn84@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-22-713_0d1e9751fc12aaee.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799709},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"10 products I've bought during the pandemic to make my home more livable","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/10-products-bought-during-lockdown-that-made-home-more-livable-2020-7","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5de6c1ddfd9db225366dc4b5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"online shopping\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Melissa Petro&#39;s quarantine shopping has been a combination of impulse buys and practical home improvement.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox / Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Melissa Petro is a freelance writer based in New York where she lives with her husband and two small children.&#160;</li>\n<li>Petro says she was never a big shopper before the pandemic, but during lockdown, she's discovered that shopping online and receiving deliveries can create something to look forward to in an otherwise monotonous day.</li>\n<li>Petro has invested in reusable glass jars, a portable carpet cleaner, colorful woven baskets, and an outdoor porch swing.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Happiness is simple: All it takes — the saying goes — is something to do, someone to love, and something to look forward to. I've got the first two covered thanks to my family, but that last one is sometimes tough, especially in the midst of a global pandemic.</p><p>Enter online shopping. Now, I've never been one of those women that stakes an identity around shopping. I've never had the time or money, and after I had kids it became less of a fun way to spend an afternoon, and more of a chore. But lockdown has led to us having a little extra to spend each month, as well as more time for me thanks to my husband helping more around the house, and so — <a href=\"https://www.timeout.com/london/news/how-bad-is-it-that-youve-developed-a-lockdown-online-shopping-habit-050620\">like a lot of people, apparently</a> — I've developed something of a habit.</p><p>Sometimes, receiving a delivery is the most excitement I get all week. I feel like my toddler when I open a \"present,\" even if it's just a 12-pack of toilet paper. It's exceptionally fun when I'm receiving something more out of the ordinary than household paper products — but even ordinary items, I've learned, can feel life-changing.</p><p>Below are the 10 best purchases I've made since the start of our sheltering in place. While \"life-changing\" may be a bit of an overstatement, these simple and mostly inexpensive products have made my home neater, cleaner, nicer, and generally more livable over the past four months.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t1. Jars, jars, and more jars\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c2f1f34d0559aa0248a5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jars. Melissa Petro\" height=\"1182\" width=\"1158\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Glass jars are useful for holding everything from knick knacks to sourdough starter.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>When the pandemic first hit, like everyone else, fear fueled a need to buy bulk. That said, I've always wanted a Pinterest-worthy pantry, and so I took it as the opportunity to invest in some eco-friendly storage ware. Jars keep everything on hand and free of pests. You can always reuse empty glass jars, but purchasing at least a handful that are identical (<a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&#38;xs=1&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tractorsupply.com%2Ftsc%2Fproduct%2Fball-regular-mouth-jars-32-oz-pack-of-12-4412819%3F\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">like these</a>) will give you a more unified look.</p>\n\t2. Lots of baskets\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c33d3ad8615024053053?format=jpeg\" alt=\"baskets. Melissa Petro\" height=\"698\" width=\"930\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Baskets are a colorful way to collect clutter around the house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>My husband makes fun of me because I am constantly buying baskets. I tell him to make fun all he wants, but you can never have too many baskets. I order baskets with no intended purpose and &#8212; sure as rain &#8212; they all find a use. When it comes to storing toys, big woven baskets are a beautiful alternative to plastic bins, and make cleaning up that sea of plastic so easy that even a toddler can do it (not that he or she necessarily will). If you want to splurge, <a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&#38;xs=1&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wayfair.com%2Fstorage-organization%2Fsb1%2Fseagrass-storage-baskets-c1860059-a9659%7E494889.html%3F\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Wayfair</a> has some pretty options.</p>\n\t3. Pegboards, for a place to hang everything\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c35bf34d055a0e45cf33?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pegboard Melissa Petro\" height=\"870\" width=\"1160\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wall storage is a great way to keep household items organized and in reach.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In addition to our disagreements over baskets, my husband and I have differing views on what needs to be done around the house and in what order. I'm an \"out of sight out of mind\" kind of person, whereas his bugbear is the basement. My husband wants it clean and organized, so he installed <a href=\"https://www.uline.com/Product/Detail/H-7791W/Pegboards/Poly-Pegboard-48-x-24-White?pricode=WA9447&#38;gadtype=pla&#38;id=H-7791W&#38;gclid=CjwKCAjwrvv3BRAJEiwAhwOdM9AFeZ-pssIqR0qpCheaV4tKuSSh9HddFSrkdpSmcvY0CRB093awaBoCGoYQAvD_BwE&#38;gclsrc=aw.ds\">pegboards</a> along the walls leading down the stairs to the basement. Turns out, his idea was a good one. A formerly dead-to-me wall has become one of my favorite spaces in the house.&#160;&#160;</p>\n\t4. The impulse buy — canvas storage bags\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15f825988ee3034e2e9cac?format=jpeg\" alt=\"melissa petro cushions\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Large canvas storage bags can house extra blankets or pillows.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Like everyone, I've made more than a couple risky and impulsive purchases this quarantine. When a Facebook ad popped up in my feed advertising these <a href=\"https://www.mangobug.com/products/designer-storage-bags\">enormous canvas storage bags in bright and modern patterns</a> I couldn't resist. Some months later &#8212; unlike the hand-embroidered mask I'd purchased at least two weeks earlier &#8212; the bags actually arrived. The material is a little thinner than I expected, but the zippers are sturdy, and the bags are even roomier than I anticipated &#8212; perfect for the extra blankets that were piled in a corner on the floor in the family room.</p>\n\t5. An outdoor haven\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c395f34d055a322c7657?format=jpeg\" alt=\"porch swing Melissa Petro\" height=\"1032\" width=\"972\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A porch swing can add comfortable outdoor seating.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>One bulk trash day last summer, I saw the potential in a hideous wooden love seat and dragged it home. After fresh coats of paint and a couple new cushions, and we've literally added an extra room to our home &#8212; priceless when you've got two kids and you're working from home. With the money we saved, I splurged on <a href=\"https://theporchswingcompany.com/products/a-l-furniture-co-traditional-english-porch-swing\">this sweet little porch swing</a>. Perfect for when the workday is over and it's time for \"date night\"!</p>\n\t6. A brand new sofa (not really, but it feels that way)\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c3aef34d055a3b627108?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sofa Melissa Petro\" height=\"790\" width=\"1166\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sometimes a deep cleaning can make an old sofa feel brand new.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Sure, sex is good, but have you ever steam cleaned a sofa? Watching the <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Bissell-3624-SpotClean-Professional-Portable/dp/B008DBRFBK/ref=as_li_ss_tl?&#38;linkCode=ll1&#38;tag=newsroom_affiliate_072120_products-bought-during-lockdown-20&#38;linkId=cf85157135120a6c319b09cc8900c394&#38;language=en_US\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Bissell 3624 SpotClean Professional Portable Carpet Cleaner</a> efficiently suck up nearly two years of pet hair, baby spit up, and toddler tracks gave me the same feeling I imagine some people get from watching pimple popping videos. Steam cleaning is my new go-to activity when I want to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-find-flow-working-from-home-during-pandemic-2020-6\">\"flow.\"</a></p>\n\t7. Ikea curtains\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c3c93f7370734578a948?format=jpeg\" alt=\"curtains Melissa Petro\" height=\"1150\" width=\"1122\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Light-colored curtains will allow in natural light while maintaining privacy.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Public health and economic crisis looming just outside the windows? Block it all out with panels of fabric! But seriously, curtains make a room look spacious and stylish &#8212; and when you're stuck at home for an indefinite period of time, it's best to enjoy the view. For those of us that go for the generic farmhouse linen-like look, all the bloggers recommended good old Ikea. I went with the <a href=\"https://www.ikea.com/us/en/p/lenda-curtains-with-tie-backs-1-pair-bleached-white-30111978/\">Lenda</a> in bleached white.</p>\n\t8. A $12 duvet cover\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c3f2988ee36ad46b2dc6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"duvet Melissa Petro\" height=\"1130\" width=\"992\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A new duvet can be an affordable option to update old bedding.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>While I was placing my Ikea order I threw in one completely unnecessary item &#8212;&#160;just kidding, I threw in at least a dozen unnecessary items (including more than a few awesome baskets), but the item most worth writing about is <a href=\"https://www.ikea.com/us/en/p/traedkrassula-duvet-cover-and-pillowcase-s-white-blue-90392824/\">this $12 duvet</a>. The pattern was even prettier in person, and as the nights heat up, it's the perfect weight.&#160;&#160;</p>\n\t9. Fresh produce delivered to my door\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c417988ee36adb0f445a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"two bird Melissa Petro\" height=\"1184\" width=\"1160\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ordering fresh groceries can help support local farmers during the pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>When our grocery store closed down due to COVID-19, we found ourselves living in a food desert and without any means of transportation. Thankfully, our neighbors at <a href=\"https://www.twobirds.studio/\">Two Birds</a> in Cold Spring, New York had our back. It's a little pricier than C-Town, but the produce is fresher so it lasts longer, and the money we save on eating out covers the difference. Some months later, our grocery store is back up and running, but I'm still ordering local produce and somehow making meals from beet greens and garlic scapes.</p>\n\t10. This $900 oil painting\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f15c4302618b974f97978b3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"painting Melissa Petro\" height=\"1046\" width=\"846\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Petro</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>My husband and I had been eyeing this painting since we first bought our home, but could never (under normal circumstances) justify making such a luxurious purchase. For the past four months, we are fortunate that we can both work remotely &#8212; and his income has not been affected &#8212; and so when our stimulus arrived, we put it towards supporting a local business we loved. The Coop in Peekskill, New York sells vintage furnishings, antiques, and unique gifts. Their brick and mortar unfortunately didn't survive the pandemic, but you can still peruse their <a href=\"https://www.thecooppeekskill.com/\">shop online</a>.&#160;&#160;</p><p><em>This article was originally published on Business Insider June 21, 2020.</em></p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Melissa Petro)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5de6c1ddfd9db225366dc4b5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn60@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-129_faf336357da7328f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c2f1f34d0559aa0248a5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn3@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-27-788_1aaa22268ddee061.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c33d3ad8615024053053?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn43@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-15-775_070d95d985ad297d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c35bf34d055a0e45cf33?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn40@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-24-616_ba17fb81894bbba1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15f825988ee3034e2e9cac?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn7@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-21-394_d11ce14e2961016a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c395f34d055a322c7657?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-24-799_07ce36140d4096de.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c3aef34d055a3b627108?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn27@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-15-630_a48f1292d16f426a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c3c93f7370734578a948?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn92@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-22-118_4dd582bcd71a7f32.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c3f2988ee36ad46b2dc6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn28@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-26-588_a714464de3ce17bc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c417988ee36adb0f445a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn43@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-26-057_dfb1b6980d1755a9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f15c4302618b974f97978b3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn100@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-16-461_b6863cebeeaae6ec.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=k7lvjalp0tE:PR9ygiiYby0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn36@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-16-807_4d706b89e07755a4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=k7lvjalp0tE:PR9ygiiYby0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn32@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-27-927_4314e44696bb5438.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=k7lvjalp0tE:PR9ygiiYby0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn11@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-20-780_52662de3bfbfd83f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/k7lvjalp0tE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-28-950_96e804ff00de0216.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799676},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"Coronavirus social bubbles might pop this winter. Here's why small gatherings aren't as safe as you may think.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/small-gatherings-and-social-bubbles-pose-coronavirus-infection-risks-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89d3d89e9fe40019009cd1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages 1243689085\" height=\"2662\" width=\"3993\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Wearing masks indoors can mitigate the risk of small gatherings.\n<p class=\"copyright\">2K Studio/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Small gatherings are an increasingly common setting for coronavirus transmission.</li>\n<li>If you're going to gather indoors, maintain a small and strict bubble and don't be afraid to ask the hard questions.</li>\n<li>Holiday celebrations and cold weather may pose challenges to bubbles, so it's important to practice safety measures such as social distancing and mask-wearing.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Coronavirus cases are surging across the US, and many transmissions are happening behind closed doors.&#160;</p><p>Small household gatherings are an increasing threat right now, Centers For Disease Control and Prevention Director Robert Redfield said in a call to governors on Tuesday, according to <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/14/health/us-coronavirus-wednesday/index.html\">CNN</a>. And with the weather getting colder and family holidays on the horizon, there will be even more occasions to gather indoors.</p><p>The problem is, most people don't have signs in their homes saying \"keep your distance, wear a mask, wash your hands,\" Peter Chin-Hong, MD, professor of medicine at University of California-San Francisco, told Insider. On top of that, you may be more likely to have your guard down among those you'd invite into your home.</p><p>\"People may think of that inner sanctum of your domicile as having a force field around COVID, but of course that isn't the case,\" Chin-Hong said.</p><p>The best way to keep your household safe is to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/prepare-for-winter-with-the-coronavirus-how-to-bubble-2020-9\">form a tight social circle, or bubble</a>, and strictly limit who you see indoors. But bubbles will pop if pushed to their limits — don't let yours burst this winter.</p><h2><strong>If you're going to form a bubble, be prepared to ask some hard questions</strong></h2><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-prevention-study-social-bubbles-2020-6\">Forming a coronavirus bubble</a> is like signing a social contract, Chin-Hong said. You're agreeing to take on whatever level of risk your bubble-mates may incur in their daily lives, and to mitigate the risk you're bringing into the bubble.&#160;</p><p>The least complicated social bubble is a single household where you're forced to be transparent about your day-to-day activities and exposures, said Barun Mathema, assistant professor of epidemiology at the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health.</p><p>If you want to expand your bubble beyond your household, you need to do your due diligence to create that transparency, Mathema told Insider. <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/how-to-talk-to-partner-about-dating-safely-during-pandemic-2020-9\">Those conversations may be awkward</a>, he said, but you can blame any social discomfort on the pandemic.</p><p>\"I've done this personally myself, saying, 'Listen, this is very awkward, but I just need to ask this question,'\" Mathema said. \"'I would be irresponsible to myself and my family, and to you and your family, if we didn't have this conversation.'\"</p><p>The bigger the bubble, the higher the chance of someone breaking the social contract, Chin-Hong said. Two family units, or eight to ten people, can be manageable, but the risk goes up if you include people from multiple households (say, eight people from four different households).</p><h2><strong>Beware of the 'super-bubble'</strong></h2><p>If you've ever seen a bubble machine churn out a stream of suds, you may have noticed that smaller bubbles tend to stick together and form a giant super-bubble. That bubble can burst at the slightest disturbance.</p><p>Mathema said the same thing can happen with coronavirus bubbles. You may think you know the goings-on within your bubble, but if someone in your group has an additional bubble, you lose control over your potential exposures.</p><p>\"At face value, it's really uncomplicated,\" Mathema said. \"But when you add in social networks and human behavior, and the fact that we are social beings, that's when things start getting very complicated very quickly.\"</p><p>There will always be some risk that comes with social contacts during the pandemic, and your willingness to bubble will depend on your individual risk tolerance, Yvonne Maldonado, MD, professor of pediatrics and infectious diseases at Stanford University, told Insider. Still, she recommends against letting your guard down completely, as you never know how careful other people are.</p><p>\"Having a pod doesn't mean that you can <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-social-distancing-might-last-several-months-2020-3\">stop socially distancing</a> and wearing masks,\" Maldonado said. \"You still have to practice some care there.\"</p><h2><strong>This holiday season might challenge your boundaries</strong></h2><p>The combination of cold weather, holiday cheer, and <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/what-is-quarantine-fatigue-how-to-combat-it-2020-5\">pandemic fatigue</a> can spell trouble for even the most carefully curated bubbles. People are tired after nearly eight months of thinking about the coronavirus, and they might be more likely to relax safety measures around family and friends.</p><p>\"It's a time when family members get together and you don't want to think of risk, either because it's the holiday time and you have lots of eggnog in you, so you lose inhibitions,\" Chin-Hong said. \"But mainly because it seems rude to not hug your Aunt Sue or your Uncle Albert when you haven't seen them for a year, and you don't know what their COVID risk is.\"</p><p><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/6-questions-to-ask-before-traveling-for-holidays-this-year-2020-10\">Asking the hard questions</a> about risk can feel contentious among family, particularly if there are incompatible risk tolerances and dissenting views on the pandemic, Mathema said.&#160;</p><p>Even if everyone is willing to wear masks inside, there's still a considerable risk. People have to take off their masks to eat, Maldonado said, so distancing is just as important.&#160;</p><p>\"It's sort of like wearing a bike helmet,\" Mathema said. \"Like, wear a bike helmet, but you should still be very careful on the bike.\"</p><p>The best way to minimize risk is to keep your bubble tight and stay vigilant at even the smallest gatherings, he said. This is not the year to reunite with the whole extended family — if possible, he recommends avoiding family outside of your regular bubble altogether.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original Read <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-plus\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">everything there is to know about Disney+ over here</a>.</p><p>And if you need some binge-spiration, here are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-movies-disney-plus\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">all the new movies available</a> to stream.</p>\n\tA smart way to add Google Assistant to any room\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5db9f684dee0195b902826f9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"100 gifts under $100 13\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Google</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?subId1=biip_103019_100-gifts-under-100&#38;u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fgoogle-home-mini-1st-generation-smart-speaker-with-google-assistant-chalk%2F6082194.p%3FskuId%3D6082194%23\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Google Home Mini, available at Best Buy, $39</a>&#160;</h3><p>The convenience and utility of Google live in this small but mighty smart home device that lets them do everything from check their calendar to play music, all hands-free.&#160;</p>\n\tA pretty leather wrap for taking chargers and cables on the go\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89f1c5d260780019341eea?format=jpeg\" alt=\"leather charger roll up o\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mark &#38; Graham</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"http://markandgraham.juo2.net/c/196318/267860/4338?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.markandgraham.com%2Fproducts%2Fleather-charger-roll-up-carrier%2F%3Fpkey%3Dcmonogrammed-personalized-tech%26isx%3D0.0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Leather Charger Roll Up, available on Mark &#38; Graham, $38.98</a></h3><p>Mark &#38; Graham's Leather Charger Roll Up is made from soft, supple leather and has three separate pockets to stash cables and chargers on the go. Get it monogrammed for free.</p>\n\tA specialty beer-making kit\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89f2609e9fe40019009dc3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mr. Beer Craft Kit\" height=\"1124\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001BCFUBU/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biip_111319_amazon-gifts-for-him-under-100-dollars-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B001BCFUBU&#38;linkId=7e4b7484c652f54297f538bbeb45c6ee\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Mr. Beer Premium Craft Making Kit, $49.99</a></h3><p>If he's one of those guys that either is or will one day be holed up in the garage making specialty beers, he's going to love this DIY kit. It's ultra-satisfying to pour the melted cheese over potatoes, meat, and vegetables.&#160;</p>\n\tGuitar picks made from quarters\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5bd1d4bd5f5e95151a43979a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"uncommongoods gifts 23\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">UncommonGoods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"http://uncommongoods.sjv.io/c/196318/483884/8444?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.uncommongoods.com%2Fproduct%2Fcustom-repurposed-quarter-guitar-picks&#38;subid2=1572887516078ac82z7e6a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored\">Custom Repurposed Quarter Guitar Picks, available at UncommonGoods, $30</a></h3><p>Coin guitar picks not only look cool but they also change the feel and sound of the music-playing experience. nsider.com/5dc05d9d2f364a7ded2db293?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn35@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-22-269_8f4e48e871dc2580.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d9ce3c6962b0c0817410fd8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn31@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-23-679_55f40207a6a1461c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5bd1d4bd5f5e95151a43979a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn3@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-27-086_23d6b9d9df539cfc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_MkzTlhqYLs:CCoGh0CW_vo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn40@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-20-090_c0580637dfbe532a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_MkzTlhqYLs:CCoGh0CW_vo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn11@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-29-355_09877835c028fa65.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_MkzTlhqYLs:CCoGh0CW_vo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn11@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-21-565_6c0043d5e1a3381b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_MkzTlhqYLs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn24@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-15-684_dde843bd7bd65735.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799777},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"How to use Skype's Meet Now feature to start or join video calls from a computer or mobile device","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-use-skype-meet-now","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f84ab43c255d800190b966d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"grandma video call with grandchild desktop video conference\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It&#39;s easy to use Skype Meet Now to place instant video calls, whether the recipient has Skype or not.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Keep It 100/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can use Skype's Meet Now feature to start instant meetings, in which participants don't need to have Skype accounts.&#160;</li>\n<li>You can start a Meet Now by selecting the Meet Now button in the desktop or mobile app, and sharing the link with other attendees.</li>\n<li>When you get an invite to Meet Now, you can join in the Chrome or Edge browsers, or via the Skype app if you have it installed.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>Meet Now is a relatively new <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/skype\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Skype</a> feature that lets you conduct meetings quickly and easily with other Skype users as well as people who have no Skype account.</p><p>It's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/microsoft\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft's</a> alternative to web conferencing tools like Zoom which have recently become popular to accommodate the increased need for remote meetings.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to start a Skype Meet Now</strong></h2><p>You can kick off Meet Now from your Skype app either on your desktop or from your mobile app.</p><ul><li><strong>On your desktop computer</strong>, start the Skype desktop app and click \"Meet Now\" on the left side of the screen. Click \"Share invite.\" In the dropdown menu, you can copy the link to send to other people outside the Skype app, or use the options in the menu to share the link via email. When you're ready, click \"Start call.\"</li></ul><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f84a713c255d800190b962f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_use_Skype_Meet_Now 1\" height=\"1153\" width=\"1529\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Meet Now is one click away on the desktop.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>On a mobile device</strong>, start the Skype app and tap the New Chat icon (it looks like a pencil). On the iPhone or iPad app, you'll find it at the top right; on Android, it's at the bottom right. Tap \"Meet Now.\" Share the meeting invite with other participants and then tap \"Start Meeting.\"</li></ul><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f84a7d191aa9e001880b112?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_use_Skype_Meet_Now 2\" height=\"2194\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>On the mobile app, you can launch Meet Now from the New Chat menu.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Once the meeting has begun, you can conduct the meeting like any ordinary Skype session.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to join a Skype Meet Now</strong></h2><p>To join a Meet Now, you need the meeting code or link, which the meeting organizer needs to share with you via email or text message. To join the meeting, you don't need to have the app installed or even have a Skype account.&#160;</p><p>To join the meeting, you need one of these three things installed on your computer or mobile device:</p><ul><li>The Skype app</li><li>Google Chrome browser</li><li>Microsoft Edge browser</li></ul><p>To join the meeting, tap or click the link. Then choose to start the app or open the meeting in a browser. That's it – you're now in the meeting. If you join without enabling the microphone, you'll be able to listen in, and can send chat messages if you need to share information.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f84a871c255d800190b9653?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_use_Skype_Meet_Now 3\" height=\"949\" width=\"1391\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>When you receive the invitation, you can choose to join the meeting in a web browser.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a using your computer or mobile device</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-delete-skype-conversation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"
