Eadicicco)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f85e24491aa9e001880b4fc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn44@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-28-811_33c33925697c17ac.webp","https://i.insider.com/5c6d537c0d15f55d816ff975?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn55@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-20-362_a52b4b6858bc3b97.webp","https://i.insider.com/5efd02102618b96b03618e7d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn12@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-19-121_6cb96225b119fb65.webp","https://i.insider.com/5cc07bc5b14bf43f0e79d5f1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn48@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-25-965_5218568bc4b01a61.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oYEiF5z8-nk:wRNXGlf5Q4E:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn3@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-15-214_afd3b9602a5a4c1e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oYEiF5z8-nk:wRNXGlf5Q4E:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn84@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-20-370_78a81dcf9b659abe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=oYEiF5z8-nk:wRNXGlf5Q4E:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn59@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-15-975_0f334f6aa3a1a68d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/oYEiF5z8-nk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn64@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-26-087_dede28a9e0229cca.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799696},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"How to leave a review and rating on the Apple Podcasts app, and view all of your reviews later","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-leave-a-review-on-apple-podcasts","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89f581d260780019341f18?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apple macos catalina apple podcasts\" height=\"816\" width=\"1632\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It&#39;s easy to leave reviews on the Apple Podcasts app.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apple</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can leave a review on the Apple Podcasts app by heading to a podcast's \"Ratings &#38; Reviews\" menu.</li>\n<li>Once you start leaving reviews, you can find all of your podcast reviews in the Apple ID menu.</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>If you're a podcast fanatic and want to shower your favorite show or host with genuine praise, writing a review in Apple's Podcast app is the perfect place.&#160;</p><p>Leaving a review, whether good or bad, is simple and can be done in just a few steps. And if you ever want to go back and review your ratings, you can see them all in one place using your Apple device's Settings app.&#160;</p><p>Here's how to do both.</p><h2><strong>How to leave a review on Apple Podcasts</strong></h2><p><strong>1. </strong>Open the Podcasts app on your iPhone, iPad, or Mac.&#160;</p><p><strong>2. </strong>Navigate to the page of the podcast you want to leave a review for. You can find it by searching for it or selecting it from your library. Just note that you'll have to go to the series page which shows all the episodes, not just the page for a single episode.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89eaf0d260780019341eb4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Podcast1\" height=\"1699\" width=\"820\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Find the podcast you want to leave a review for.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Meira Gebel/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>3. </strong>Scroll down to find the subhead titled \"Ratings &#38; Reviews.\"</p><p><strong>4. </strong>Under one of the highlighted reviews, select \"Write a Review.\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89eb129e9fe40019009d87?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Podcast2\" height=\"1705\" width=\"824\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Tap or click the &#34;Write a Review&#34; option.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Meira Gebel/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>5. </strong>Next, select a star rating at the top — you have the option of choosing between one and five stars.&#160;</p><p><strong>6. </strong>Using the text box at the top, write a title for your review. Then, in the lower text box, write your review. Your review can be up to 300 words long.</p><p><strong>7. </strong>Once you've finished, select \"Send\" or \"Save\" in the top-right corner.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89eb889e9fe40019009d89?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Podcast3\" height=\"1684\" width=\"828\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Write your review and send it.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Meira Gebel/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>8. </strong>If you've never left a podcast review before, enter a nickname. Your nickname will be displayed next to any reviews you leave from here on out.&#160;</p><p><strong>9. </strong>After selecting a nickname, tap OK. Your review may not be immediately visible, but assuming you didn't write anything offensive or spammy, it should be posted soon.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to see the reviews you've already left on Apple Podcasts</strong></h2><p>Note that you can only do this on an iPhone or iPad, not a Mac.</p><p><strong>1. </strong>Navigate to the Settings app on your iPhone or iPad and tap your name at the top of the page. This will open your Apple ID menu.</p><p><strong>2. </strong>Tap \"Media &#38; Purchases.\"&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89f1c1d260780019341ee9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"podcast review 7.PNG\" height=\"1792\" width=\"830\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You&#39;ll find the &#34;Media &#38; Purchases&#34; tab in your Apple ID menu.\n<p class=\"copyright\">William Antonelli/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>3. </strong>In the middle of the page, select \"Ratings and Reviews.\" You'll now be able to see all the ratings and reviews you've left using your Apple ID.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89f1f69e9fe40019009dc1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"podcast review 8.PNG\" height=\"1792\" width=\"828\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>View your ratings and reviews.\n<p class=\"copyright\">William Antonelli/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>If you're using an older version of iOS, you might not see these options. Instead, open the Settings app and tap \"iTunes and App Store,\" and then tap your Apple ID — you'll be able to find your reviews there.</p><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-add-apple-podcasts-to-sonos\">How to add Apple Podcasts to your Sonos speaker using AirPlay</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/can-alexa-play-podcasts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"a688e347de31430ddda811ebfe767354\">How to play podcasts on your Alexa-enabled smart speaker</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-play-podcasts-on-google-home\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"98b550f915e084a8b94fd24fa3a9a3b5\">How to play podcasts on your Google Home smart speaker in 2 different ways</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-listen-to-podcasts-on-mac\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"ddf6a56f6d4637577f6992851d01c8cc\">How to find, listen to, and delete podcasts on your Mac using the new Podcasts app</a></h3></li><li><h3><a listen to podcasts on your iPhone, where you can access over 700,000 podcasts from Apple's catalog</a></h3></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/J9FZjJHWc7Q\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 16 Oct 2020 21:55:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f89f54dd260780019341f14?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"6abed0419353916d95b6a08c0ef5471a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn46@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-14-145_b81f5bc6cf03195d.webp","destWidth":1375,"destHeight":1031,"sourceBytes":67074,"destBytes":67074,"author":"insider@insider.com (Meira Gebel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89f581d260780019341f18?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn35@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-23-159_c273e12b547ba461.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89eaf0d260780019341eb4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn31@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-18-385_52b738f4559df638.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89eb129e9fe40019009d87?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn39@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-28-826_c9514af6b095117d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89eb889e9fe40019009d89?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn16@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-22-958_8678be53a6fec8a6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89f1c1d260780019341ee9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn11@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-16-524_53f177a7d7d57f78.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89f1f69e9fe40019009dc1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn24@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-19-279_2ed16d41d7fb3ebc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=J9FZjJHWc7Q:AvOahTSkJos:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn95@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-18-974_6f93e9896bdb6c15.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=J9FZjJHWc7Q:AvOahTSkJos:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn40@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-21-665_934e106cc41dd68e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=J9FZjJHWc7Q:AvOahTSkJos:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-28-472_24779d0a6fb7996f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/J9FZjJHWc7Q":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn32@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-24-589_3fd2e8091905ffcc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799669},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"Understanding the way compound interest works is key to building wealth or avoiding crushing debt. Here's how to make it work for you","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-compound-interest","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f86497efd1f49001964d7a0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"abstract dolls\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The more frequently  interest  compounds, the faster an overall amount of money accumulates.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pier/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Compound interest occurs when previously earned interest is added to the principal amount invested or borrowed. It is commonly described as \"interest earned on interest.\"</li>\n<li>Compound interest can work to your advantage as your investments grow over time, but against you if you're paying off debt, like credit cards.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li>If you're borrowing money, you want interest compounded as infrequently as possible; if you're investing, you want interest compounded as often as possible.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>Visit Insider's Investing Reference library for more stories</strong></a><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\"><strong>.</strong></a></li>\n</ul><p>Warren Buffet once famously said that his wealth came from \"a combination of living in America, some lucky genes, and compound interest.\"&#160;</p><p>The billionaire investor meant that the interest his investments earned helped create his fortune. But Buffett also liked to warn people about the dangers of ending up on the wrong side of the compound interest equation.</p><p>While compound interest is arguably the most important component to wealth-building, it can also be one of the best ways to wreck your finances: Having to <em>pay</em> compound interest can cause debt to spiral out of control.&#160;</p><p>Most people only think of interest in terms of how high or low a rate is. But understanding how interest is calculated, or compounds, is important too. Knowing how compound interest works can help you avoid expensive mistakes and make the most of your money, whether you're depositing it, investing it, borrowing it, or spending it.&#160;</p><h2>What is compound interest?</h2><p>All interest is a percentage charged on, or earned by, a lump sum of money. Compound interest is a kind of interest based on adding the original principal — that is, the initial amount invested or borrowed — with the accumulated interest from previous periods.</p><p>For example, say you have $100 in a savings account, and it earns interest at a 10% rate, compounded annually. At the end of the first year, you'd have $110 (100 in principal + 10 in interest). At the end of the second year, you'd have $121 (110 in principal + 11 in interest). At the end of the third year, you'd have $133.10 (121 in principal + 12.10 in interest). And so on.</p><p>In other words, with compound interest, you earn interest on interest.&#160;</p><p>The revelation comes when you realize that compounding interest makes the principal grow exponentially, meaning as interest accrues and the quantity of money increases, the rate of growth becomes faster.</p><p>How quickly your money grows depends on the interest rate, and the frequency of compounding. Interest can be compounded daily, monthly, quarterly, or annually, and the more frequently it's compounded, the faster it accumulates.&#160;</p><p>Over the long term, \"the magic of compounding\" can really add up. Here's how an initial investment of $5,000 would grow if compounded semi-annually over a period of 35 years, at an annualized 5% interest rate:</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"How compound interest can make $5,000 grow\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-OAwWX\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/OAwWX/6/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"536\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><p>If you're the one <em>earning </em>money off the interest, daily or monthly compounding are preferable to yearly. On the other hand, if you're being <em>charged</em> interest, monthly or yearly compounding will save you money compared to daily.</p><h2>Compound interest vs. simple interest</h2><p>While compound interest is \"interest on interest\" — calculated on both the principal amount and the accumulated interest — simple interest is wholly different. Simple interest is calculated <em>only</em> on the original principal balance or deposit.</p><p>Let's take our $100 savings account again, only this time it's paying 10% in simple interest. That means the 10% interest rate applies only to your original principal amount of $100, so you earn $10 each year. Period. At the end of the first year, you'd have $110. But at the end of the second year, you'd have $120. At the end of the third year, $130 — compared to $133.10 in the compounded interest account.</p><p>Even though we've used small numbers here, you can see how the farther out you go, the more compound interest nets you — and the more it outstrips simple interest.</p><p>Simple interest tends to be used in most student loans, mortgages, and installment loans — when you're paying a store for the purchase of a big appliance over a period of time, for example.</p><h2>How to calculate compound interest</h2><p>Calculating compound interest looks complicated, but it's actually as simple as plugging some numbers into the right formula.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f88cd009e9fe40019009aa3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"formula for compound interest\" height=\"1054\" width=\"1667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The compound interest equation basically adds 1 to the interest rate, raises this sum to the total number of compound periods, and multiplies the result by the principal amount.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shayanne Gal/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Let's say you decide to deposit your $10,000 annual bonus into a 5-year certificate of deposit (CD). You leave that money in the CD for the full five years, and it earns a 4% annual rate of interest that's compounded daily. The numbers you'd plug into each variable are as follows:</p><ul><li>P = $10,000</li><li>r = 0.04</li><li>n = 365</li><li>t = 5</li></ul><p>The formula gives you $12,213.89 for A. That's the total amount of money you'd have in your money market account at the end of five years. This means you earned $2,213.89 in interest.</p><h2>How compound interest can work against you</h2><p>As beneficial compounding interest can be for savings, investments, and wealth creation, it's important to note that it can work against you if you're paying off debt. In fact, compounding is part of what makes carrying an outstanding credit card balance so deadly.</p><p>In fact, the above example could be turned upside down by imagining that you carry a $10,000 balance on a credit card (we'll assume it's the same 4% compounded daily, even though credit card APRs are usually much higher). You plan not to put anything else on the card, and to pay it all off in five years. Even though you'd be chipping away at your balance and paying an extremely low interest rate, you could still end up paying a lot in interest charges — more than $1,000 in fact.</p><p>And if you were being charged 18% compounded daily — which is closer to the average credit card interest rate — you would pay $5,236 in interest after five years.</p><h2>How to get the most out of compound interest</h2><p>The best way to take advantage of compound interest is through saving and investing.&#160;</p><p>Opting for a savings account that earns interest — such as high-yield savings accounts, money market accounts, and CDs — is one way to make compound interest work in your favor. When choosing an account, you'll want to look for one with minimal fees and the highest annual percentage yield (<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/what-is-apy-annual-percentage-yield\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">APY</a>), which is the interest you can earn on your deposit in a 12-month period.</p><p>It's worth noting that the interest rates on even the best savings accounts barely outpace inflation, so they're best for short-term savings. If you want to build long-term wealth, whether that's savings for retirement or a goal that's years away, investing your money will really get it working for you.&#160;</p><p>Savings products offer interest rates that typically range from 0.01% to 3%, depending on the state of the economy, while the average historical rate of return on the stock market is 10%, before adjusting for inflation.</p><p>When opening an investment account like a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-a-401k-for-retirement\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">401(k)</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-open-an-ira-for-retirement\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">IRA</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-brokerage-account-first-step-towards-investing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">brokerage account</a>, or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/etf-vs-mutual-fund\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">mutual fund</a>, you have the option to automatically reinvest the dividends or interest your investments earn. Doing so means your returns will compound.</p><h2>The financial takeaway</h2><p>Compound interest can be your friend or your enemy, with the power to enrich you or bankrupt you — depending which side of it you're on.</p><p>Luckily, you don't need to be a math genius to understand whether the interest on an account will help or hurt you. If you're borrowing money, you want the lowest interest rate possible, compounded as infrequently as possible. If you're investing money, the opposite applies: You want not only a good interest rate, but one that compounds early and often.</p><p>And when comparing loans, credit card APRs, savings account APYs, or other securities' returns — check the frequency at which the interest compounds, and make sure you're comparing like to like. Two interest rates can be nominally the same, but if they compound at different speeds, it can make a big difference.&#160;</p><p>Whether earning it or paying it, the nature of compound interest means that getting on top of it early on is exponentially — pun intended — better for your wallet.</p><h2>Related Coverage in&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"1b4b1b102a76bd3c1b16e44162761b54\">Investing</a>:</h2><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/how-does-interest-work-on-bank-accounts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How banks can pay interest on your money</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/how-can-i-make-more-interest-on-my-money\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">6 easy ways to grow your money with very little effort</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/what-is-ira-cd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">An IRA CD is a conservative investment account for people nearing retirement</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-good-interest-rate-on-a-credit-card\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">What is a good interest rate on a credit card?</a></h3><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-calculate-credit-card-interest-apr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to calculate your credit card interest to figure out exactly how much your unpaid balances will cost you</a></h3><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-compound-interest'>Business +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8649b891aa9e001880b811?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"eec37ed39c989fdc1145a12ebbab957a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn63@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-14-589_8c780e408a008861.webp","destWidth":2853,"destHeight":2140,"sourceBytes":50336,"destBytes":50336,"author":"ehoffman@businessinsider.com (Elizabeth Aldrich)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f86497efd1f49001964d7a0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn63@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-24-009_fa342c094086bd4e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f88cd009e9fe40019009aa3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn63@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-27-479_b381133c5392318c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2QRX8bdCcxU:ZzhqANI6xck:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-16-574_b1fd3f46fc8be0fb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2QRX8bdCcxU:ZzhqANI6xck:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn60@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-25-617_afd4b875ab6861bb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2QRX8bdCcxU:ZzhqANI6xck:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn75@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-18-205_bacaeefaf2c2411a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/2QRX8bdCcxU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn96@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-24-951_c7088ae379ec1b3e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799717},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"How to delete podcasts stored on your Apple Watch from your iPhone's Watch app","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-delete-podcasts-from-apple-watch","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f876f90ea23a5001903d71d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apple Watch 6 Blue\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can delete podcasts stored on your Apple Watch to free up crucial space.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lisa Eadicicco/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can delete all stored podcasts from your Apple Watch, or all episodes of a particular podcast by changing your settings in your iPhone's Watch app.</li>\n<li>If the \"Custom\" option is selected in your iPhone's Watch app, your watch will store several episodes of any podcasts you select.</li>\n<li>To delete podcast episodes, turn off the desired podcast in the Podcast section of the Watch app or switch the playback mode from \"Custom\" to \"Up Next.\"&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>By default, your <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/apple-watch\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apple Watch</a> syncs one episode of each podcast you are subscribed to, but if you have manually downloaded podcasts to your watch, they can take up a lot of precious storage space. You can clear out that space by deleting podcasts using the Watch app on your <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">iPhone</a>.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to delete podcasts from an <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fapple-watch-series-6-gps-40mm-aluminum-case-with-pink-sand-sport-band-gold%2F6215922.p%3FskuId%3D6215922\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Apple Watch</a></strong></h2><p>It's only necessary to delete podcasts manually if you are using the Watch app's \"Custom\" mode for adding episodes to your watch.&#160;</p><p><strong>1.</strong> Open the Watch app on your <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fiphone%2Fiphone-11-shop-by-carrier%2Fpcmcat1568147287090.c%3Fid%3Dpcmcat1568147287090%26irclickid%3D1cmX7mXacxyOWblxU-SAVSQkUkE0fB0cwx2wSM0%26irgwc%3D1%26ref%3D198%26loc%3DBusiness%2520Insider.%26acampID%3D0%26mpid%3D196318\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">iPhone</a>.</p><p><strong>2.</strong> Tap \"Podcasts\" from the list of apps.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f876b3a2a400c0019debbbb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_delete_podcasts_from_Apple_Watch 1\" height=\"2593\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Find Podcasts in the Apple Watch&#39;s list of apps.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>3.</strong> In the \"Add Episodes From\" section, check to see if \"Custom\" is selected. If it is, then your watch might have a bunch of podcast episodes stored on it. If \"Up Next\" is selected, there are no podcasts on your <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fapple-watch-series-6-gps-40mm-aluminum-case-with-pink-sand-sport-band-gold%2F6215922.p%3FskuId%3D6215922\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">watch</a>.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f876bbcea23a5001903d70d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_delete_podcasts_from_Apple_Watch 2\" height=\"2600\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Custom option enables your watch to download podcast episodes.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The \"Choose Shows\" section lists all the podcasts you are subscribed to in the <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fiphone%2Fiphone-11-shop-by-carrier%2Fpcmcat1568147287090.c%3Fid%3Dpcmcat1568147287090%26irclickid%3D1cmX7mXacxyOWblxU-SAVSQkUkE0fB0cwx2wSM0%26irgwc%3D1%26ref%3D198%26loc%3DBusiness%2520Insider.%26acampID%3D0%26mpid%3D196318\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">iPhone</a>'s Podcasts app. Each podcast that is turned on (the button is green and swiped to the right) is configured to keep the most recent three episodes on your <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fapple-watch-series-6-gps-40mm-aluminum-case-with-pink-sand-sport-band-gold%2F6215922.p%3FskuId%3D6215922\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Apple Watch</a>.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f876cafea23a5001903d711?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_delete_podcasts_from_Apple_Watch 3\" height=\"2597\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can selectively turn off specific podcasts, which immediately deletes any episodes that were stored on your watch.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>4.</strong> To delete all the stored podcasts at once, tap \"Up Next\" in the \"Add Episodes From\" section. This will delete all podcasts from your watch and only make the current episode available to you.</p><p>Alternatively, to delete all the episodes in a specific podcast, keep the selection on \"Custom,\" but turn off the desired podcast by swiping its button to the left. This deletes all the episodes in that podcast, but leaves the other podcasts' episodes on your watch.</p><p>Unfortunately, there's no way to selectively delete individual episodes from your watch – it's either all the episodes in a particular podcast or all the podcasts entirely.</p><div id=\"ProductCard_5d8e19fb2e22af18f40d281d\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5d8e19fb2e22af18f40d281d&type=small&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><div id=\"ProductCard_5f6cfb0302495a07337f0624\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5f6cfb0302495a07337f0624&type=small&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" without an iPhone nearby, and seamlessly track all your exercise data</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-reset-apple-watch-password\" target=\"_blank\" 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"The ousted founder of Facebook's virtual-reality unit Oculus is paying a bounty to anyone who can hack his former employer's new virtual-reality headset","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/palmer-lucky-offers-5000-bounty-hack-facebook-oculus-vr-headset-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89d7549e9fe40019009cf7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"palmer luckey\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Oculus and Anduril Founder Palmer Luckey speaks during the Web Summit 2018 in Lisbon, Portugal on November 8, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pedro Fiúza/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Ex-Facebook and Oculus executive Palmer Luckey <a href=\"https://twitter.com/palmerluckey/status/1317210338480197632?s=21\">tweeted Friday</a>&#160;he is offering a $5,000 bounty to anyone who can crack the security on his former employer's new virtual-reality headset.</li>\n<li>Luckey said he would match an offer for a \"jailbreak\" of the new Oculus Quest 2 headset, and asked: \"who else is in?\"</li>\n<li>Luckey, who cofounded Oculus before <a href=\"https://about.fb.com/news/2014/03/facebook-to-acquire-oculus/\">selling it to Facebook for $2 billion</a> in 2014, was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/oculus-cofounder-palmer-luckey-leaves-facebook-2017-3\">ousted from the company in 2017</a> amid controversies surrounding his donations to a pro-Trump group and an IP lawsuit that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-ordered-to-pay-zenimax-500-million-in-oculus-vr-lawsuit-verdict-2017-2\">cost Facebook $250 million</a>.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Palmer Luckey, the Oculus VR cofounder who was ousted from Facebook amid controversy after selling his company to the tech giant for $2 billion, is offering a $5,000 bounty to anyone who can hack Oculus' new <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-oculus-quest-2-price-release-date-2020-9\">Quest 2 virtual-reality headset</a>.</p><p>\"I'm still offering $5000 for a Quest 2 jailbreak! Jailbreakers, dm me. Let's break free of FB's anti-competitive, anti-privacy ecosystem!\" Mozilla VR engineer Robert Long <a href=\"https://twitter.com/arobertlong/status/1316177057085177857\">tweeted</a> Friday.</p><p>\"I will match this, who else is in?\" <a href=\"https://twitter.com/palmerluckey/status/1317210338480197632?s=21\">Luckey replied</a>.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Palmer Luckey  (@PalmerLuckey) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1317210338480197632?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">October 16, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Facebook did not respond to a request for comment on this story.</p><p>After selling Oculus to Facebook in 2014, Luckey gained notoriety in 2016 following <a href=\"https://www.thedailybeast.com/palmer-luckey-the-facebook-near-billionaire-secretly-funding-trumps-meme-machine\">The Daily Beast's report</a> that he had donated to a controversial pro-Trump group called Nimble America that had reportedly ran misogynistic and white-supremacist political ads during that year's presidential election.</p><p>Luckey was eventually <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/oculus-cofounder-palmer-luckey-leaves-facebook-2017-3\">ousted from Facebook in 2017</a>, which <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/why-did-facebook-fire-a-top-executive-hint-it-had-something-to-do-with-trump-1541965245\">The Wall Street Journal</a> reported was due to his association with Nimble America. CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified to Congress in 2018 that Luckey's firing wasn't due \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/who-is-palmer-luckey-why-is-ted-cruz-asking-mark-zuckerberg-about-firing-him-2018-4\">to a political view.</a>\"</p><p>His termination also came shortly after a judge handed down a verdict in a lawsuit brought against Oculus by VR startup Zenimax, which had accused Oculus and Luckey of stealing its intellectual property. The court ruled for Oculus on those accusations, but the jury's ruling that Oculus violated nondisclosure agreements ultimately <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-zenimax-oculus-vr-lawsuit-explained-2017-2#while-deciding-oculus-was-innocent-the-jury-emalsoem-decided-to-award-zenimax-500-million-for-violations-of-non-disclosure-agreements-heres-who-was-ordered-to-pay-and-how-much-12\">cost Facebook $250 million</a>.</p><p>Luckey, a longtime Trump supporter who is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/palmer-luckey-donald-trump-fundraisiner-reelection-campaign-2020-10\">hosting a fundraiser for the president</a> this weekend, has since founded Andruil, a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/anduril-raises-200-million-nearly-2-billion-valuation-andreessen-horowitz-2020-7\">$2 billion defense tech company</a> that recently won a contract from the Trump administration to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/anduril-peter-thiel-backed-startup-trump-virtual-border-wall-2020-7\">build a virtual border \"wall\"</a> on the US-Mexico border.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/palmer-lucky-offers-5000-bounty-hack-facebook-oculus-vr-headset-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=n55SohAgSNg:s9QuDxHzeoQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 17 Oct 2020 00:04:45 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8a1cf19e9fe40019009e91?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"bd1fe1ea009ed9bc95b6f847d42b7b99","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn47@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-15-060_2d509d5f18480419.webp","destWidth":1778,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":171270,"destBytes":171270,"author":"tsonnemaker@businessinsider.com (Tyler Sonnemaker)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89d7549e9fe40019009cf7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn80@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-21-347_85eabeec9062bd08.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=n55SohAgSNg:s9QuDxHzeoQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn91@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-18-113_90457d2949945aba.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=n55SohAgSNg:s9QuDxHzeoQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn64@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-26-785_ab1c4f414446637d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=n55SohAgSNg:s9QuDxHzeoQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn3@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-16-590_e8e17fa390bf0b82.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/n55SohAgSNg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-18-060_fa4f970c61e4513b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799719},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"How to change your Epic Games display name, so that people you play with can see you with a new title","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-change-epic-games-name","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8a00949e9fe40019009e3d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Epic Games\" height=\"1476\" width=\"2952\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It&#39;s easy to change your Epic Games display name.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Photo Illustration by Rafael Henrique/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><strong>You can change your Epic Games name by heading to your \"Account Info\" page.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Once you change your Epic Games display name, you'll have to wait at least two weeks to change it again.</strong></li>\n<li><strong>Your Epic Games display name is the name used to identify yourself in games like \"Fortnite\" and \"Rogue Company.\"</strong></li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/epic-games\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Epic Games</a> is the developer behind the multiplayer sensation \"Fortnite.\" But there are hundreds of games on the Epic Games Store, and many of them make use of your display name.</p><p>You choose a display name when you sign up for an Epic Games account — it's how you identify yourself in-game and on other Epic platforms.&#160;</p><p>If you're tired of your current Epic Games name, you can change it at any time. Just note that once you can only change your display name once every two weeks.</p><h2><strong>How to change your Epic Games name</strong></h2><p>If you're playing on Playstation or Xbox, changing your Epic Games name won't affect your gamertag or display name — those systems use your PlayStation Network and Xbox Live name, respectively.</p><p>But if you play on your PC, Mac, or Nintendo Switch, using <a href=\"https://www.epicgames.com/help/en-US/epic-accounts-c74/general-support-c79/how-do-i-upgrade-a-console-or-platform-account-to-a-full-epic-games-account-a3248\">a \"Full\" Epic Games account</a>, changing your Epic Games name will change your name in Epic Games titles on those systems.</p><p><strong>1. </strong>Open your web browser and <a href=\"https://www.epicgames.com/id/login?lang=en-US&noHostRedirect=true&redirectUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.epicgames.com%2Fstore%2Fen-US%2F&client_id=875a3b57d3a640a6b7f9b4e883463ab4b4e883463ab4\">log into your Epic Games Account</a> if you haven't already.</p><p><strong>2. </strong>Visit this <a href=\"https://www.epicgames.com/account/personal\">Account Info</a> page and click the blue pencil icon next to your display name.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89fda8d260780019341f5a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to change Epic Games name 1\" height=\"1328\" width=\"2560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Open your Account Info settings.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Vivian McCall/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>3. </strong>Enter your new display name twice.</p><p><strong>4. </strong>Check the box confirming that you understand that display names can be changed once every two weeks.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89fdd8d260780019341f5b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to change Epic Games name 3\" height=\"1441\" width=\"2560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You&#39;ll have to confirm your new name by typing it twice.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Vivian McCall/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>5. </strong>Scroll to the bottom of the page and hit \"Save Changes.\"</p><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-download-nvidia-drivers\">How to download Nvidia drivers to border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7wanZ-WqLes\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 16 Oct 2020 21:59:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8a003fd260780019341f6a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a5cc0bf800b6817411733a2d3c481a58","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-15-046_c1f385d63386d287.webp","destWidth":2892,"destHeight":2169,"sourceBytes":108218,"destBytes":108218,"author":"insider@insider.com (Vivian McCall)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8a00949e9fe40019009e3d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn96@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-23-553_93bd2970aec3c160.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89fda8d260780019341f5a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn68@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-28-976_4580384c864fae59.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f89fdd8d260780019341f5b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn10@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-14-654_70e271d7d101d586.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7wanZ-WqLes:loA3gqUBm7c:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn87@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-20-558_ce24a9a2a1135074.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7wanZ-WqLes:loA3gqUBm7c:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn88@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-27-724_a786299c15e2a0dd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7wanZ-WqLes:loA3gqUBm7c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn91@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-21-220_86819122cf1a027d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7wanZ-WqLes":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_1/2020/10/17/02-30-22-672_a84ed4a695751711.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799719},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"Emulators can turn your PC into a Mac, let you play games from any era, and more — here's what you should know about the potential benefits and risks of using one","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-an-emulator","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f878b85ea23a5001903d775?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Laptops 1\" height=\"1125\" width=\"2250\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Emulators can be an incredibly useful  tool on your computer.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hollis Johnson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>An emulator is typically a program that lets you run software from a completely different device on your computer.</li>\n<li>The most common uses for emulators are to play video games and run different operating systems &#8212; for example, you can put a Mac operating system on your Windows computer.</li>\n<li>Emulators can allow you to run apps that normally wouldn't work on your computer.</li>\n<li>Most emulators tend to run slower than the device they're simulating, and can potentially take a lot of processing power.</li>\n<li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>An <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/emulators\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">emulator</a> is a computer program (or occasionally custom computer hardware) that's designed to simulate another kind of device.&#160;</p><p>For example, WINE is a program that allows you to run Windows software on certain Linux and Mac computers. Dolphin is an app that lets you play Nintendo GameCube and Wii games on your computer. Even Logic Pro X, the popular music recording app for Mac, lets you simulate the sound of a guitar amplifier within your computer.</p><p>These are all different types of emulators. Here's what you should know about emulators, including why people use them, how they commonly work, and what kinds there are.</p><h2><strong>Why people use emulators&#160;</strong></h2><p>Every kind of computer and operating system is unique. This often means that a program or app that works on one system won't work on another.</p><p>This is especially true when comparing operating systems like Windows and MacOS, or completely different devices like a laptop and a PlayStation.</p><p>This is where emulators come in. Emulators can bridge the gap between these devices, allowing programs to work on all sorts of hardware.</p><p>For example, if you have a Windows app that you need to run on your MacBook, you can download the Parallels emulator. Parallels will, in a sense, create a Windows computer inside of your MacBook — this will let you run any Windows app you need.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8778922a400c0019debbe8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Parallels Desktop 16 for Mac\" height=\"1875\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Here, Windows 10 and an older version of MacOS are running on a new MacBook using emulators.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Parallels Newsroom</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Some emulators can even enhance the hardware that they're simulating. For instance, old video games made for 4:3 televisions can be upgraded to run in widescreen resolution, as well as at a higher framerate.</p><p>If you're someone who likes to be able to run all their programs anywhere, at any time, then an emulator is what you need.</p><p>However, there are some risks that you should be aware of.</p><h2><strong>The downsides to emulators</strong></h2><p>Because emulators need to reproduce the behavior of an entirely different device, without having their own dedicated hardware or power source, emulators are often slower than the system they're simulating.&#160;</p><p>This is especially true if you're emulating a new system. For example, nearly any computer can emulate an '80s-era Nintendo Entertainment System without much delay. But you'll need a powerful graphics card and CPU to emulate the Nintendo Switch, which only came out in 2017. And even then, it might be hard to make that Switch emulator run smoothly.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f877f482a400c0019debbfd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mario Odyssey on Windows\" height=\"710\" width=\"1139\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You&#39;ll need a powerful computer to run most new AAA games.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fTWeVBl6xzA\" target=\"_blank\">BSoD Gaming/YouTube</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Users also have to be careful not to download a virus masquerading as an emulator. Be sure to only download emulators and programs from sources that you trust, and always do your research before installing anything.</p><p>Lastly, there's also a legal risk. Although emulators are legal almost everywhere, downloading programs to use on those emulators without paying for them may not be. Look up the regulations surrounding emulated programs in your country before downloading them.</p><h4><strong>The most popular types of emulators in use today</strong></h4><p>The two most common uses for emulators are ones for playing video games, and ones for running other operating systems. Here's a few examples of the most popular emulators around.</p><p><strong>Video game emulators</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dolphin </strong>lets you play Nintendo GameCube and Wii games on a computer, as well as modify them in various ways. Some originally single-player games even have online multiplayer modes added to them.</li><li><strong>MAME</strong> is an open-source emulator originally released in 1997 that's designed to run older arcade games.</li><li><strong>VisualBoyAdvance</strong>, or <strong>VBA</strong>, can run nearly every Game Boy, Game Boy Color, and Game Boy Advance game ever released.</li></ul><p>There are also various game emulators <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-galaxy-s8-nintendo-gamecube-games-2017-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">that run on Android phones</a>.</p><p><strong>Operating system emulators</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Parallels</strong> and <strong>WINE</strong> both allow you to run Windows on a Mac computer. It'll open a Windows desktop in a new window, just like any other app.</li><li><strong>BlueStacks</strong> lets you download and open Android apps on a desktop computer.</li><li><strong>Xcode</strong> is a program designed and released by Apple that can run iPhone apps on a Mac. Soon, Apple claims that there will be an even easier way to emulate both iPhone and iPad apps on your Mac.</li></ul><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4c86c1c3a45644bf07d168dc4c802e5e\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-are-drivers-on-windows\" data-analytics-position=\"1\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Your Windows computer runs using 'Drivers' — here's what they are, and how to find them</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-connect-pc-to-tv-wirelessly\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"cf139d28cf2b3897df4beeb9a25081da\">How to connect a PC to your TV wirelessly in 3 different ways, to watch movies, browse the internet, or stream games</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-download-nvidia-drivers\" data-analytics-position=\"22\" data-analytics-module=\"\">How to download Nvidia drivers to keep your computer's graphics running smoothly and vibrantly</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-run-iphone-apps-on-mac\" data-analytics-position=\"27\" play 4K movies — here's how to set it up</a></h3></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-an-emulator'>Business +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f878a5e2a400c0019debc19?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"8ca7ca436a2f477cc7aef5baf55947b6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn92@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-15-201_b4bfc6088846797f.webp","destWidth":1999,"destHeight":1500,"sourceBytes":109698,"destBytes":109698,"author":"insider@insider.com (Dave Johnson,William Antonelli)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f878b85ea23a5001903d775?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn96@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-16-252_51ab85b6b50b1f14.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f8778922a400c0019debbe8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn84@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-19-085_81831f0a7eb5ef26.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f877f482a400c0019debbfd?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn27@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-19-967_110281c2f876dfcc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=yrnP5I2Gu1w:DtUSrD9d-08:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn72@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-27-573_f6604ad384f03501.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=yrnP5I2Gu1w:DtUSrD9d-08:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn48@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-24-642_9198c766a1f544fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=yrnP5I2Gu1w:DtUSrD9d-08:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn7@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-24-405_0dbfac58688d9c3d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/yrnP5I2Gu1w":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-17-690_606606c0e3340a41.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799687},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"Job diary: I've been a professional tarot card reader for over 20 years — here's what my days are like","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/professional-tarot-reader-heres-what-my-days-are-like-2020-7","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f245bfb28ea712ca91a4979?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Patti Woods\" height=\"901\" width=\"1202\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The author Patti Woods during a virtual tarot card reading during the pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Patti Woods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li>Patti Woods, 49, has been a professional tarot card reader for over 20 years.</li><li>Although she stopped holding in-person sessions during the pandemic, she says people are still reaching out to her for virtual readings.</li><li>She charges $50 for a half-hour session and works out of a spare room in her home.</li><li>A reputable reader won't tell you that someone in your family is going to die or that there's curse placed on your love life — that's a scam, Woods says.</li><li>Her goal with every reading is to make sure the client feels some sense of hope.</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li></ul><p>I got my first deck of tarot cards when I was 18 years old. Even as a kid, I was fascinated by mysterious and magical things. My mother used to <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2015/09/01/434621010/for-centuries-people-have-searched-for-answers-in-the-bottom-of-a-tea-cup\">read our tea leaves</a> for fun and I was always intrigued by how a few leaves bunched together could tell so much about a person.</p><p>When I discovered tarot at the age of 12 after my sister brought home some cards, I was immediately hooked. Now I'm 49, and I read the cards every day.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2318aba6f0e17b1873cac5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Patti Woods\" height=\"2886\" width=\"3848\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Patti Woods.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Patti Woods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Some people refer to tarot reading as fortune telling, but I think of them as a tool to divine information about a person's circumstances.&#160;</p><p>There are 78 cards in a tarot deck. There are four suits (just like playing cards, except the suits are wands, swords, pentacles, and cups; this is referred to as the Minor Arcana) and then there's the Major Arcana, which are cards that are labelled things like The Fool, The Lovers, Death, and The Sun. These are the ones you always see in movies right before something ominous is about to happen, and is why the cards sometimes get a bad rap. There's no reason to fear getting your cards read. A reputable reader isn't going to tell you that anyone is going to die or that you have a curse placed upon you — that's a scam. In a legitimate tarot reading, the cards that are pulled and the way they are spread out will create a unique message that your reader will interpret.&#160;</p><h2>I learned by reading books and getting my own cards read.</h2><p>This was, of course, way before the internet. I practiced on friends and family members, initially reading from the \"LWB,\" (little white book) that comes with the cards. It's a lot like learning another language. Eventually you get to a point where the cards just seem to talk to you. You develop a rapport with them.&#160;</p><p>I started reading professionally in the 1990s.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f231268f0f419017c251034?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The author&#39;s very first deck along with the little white book. Patti Woods\" height=\"360\" width=\"481\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>One of the author&#39;s decks of tarot cards.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Patti Woods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>I'm a freelance writer, which is a solitary profession, so reading cards allows me to connect with people. At first, I started out doing private readings and a few parties, but it wasn't until the past five years or so when I really decided that this was my calling. Now I do more tarot and less writing.</p><p>I know that when I tell people I'm a reader, the first thing they think of is the stereotype: A neon sign that says \"Fortunes Told,\" a shiny crystal ball on the table, and someone telling them they can remove a hex for an extra $50. But that's not how I operate.&#160;</p><p>I read out of my home in Connecticut and at a few local shops. A basic reading is $50 for a half hour. My readings are all about the here and now. The cards are a tool to help you see what factors need to be considered when making a decision. They highlight opportunities, hindrances, helpers, and detractors. A good reading can validate past decisions and help guide you in future choices.&#160;</p><h2>I start every day by prepping my space, which is a spare room in my house.</h2><p>Although I'm currently not seeing clients in person due to COVID-19, I still want to make my space as sacred and still as possible, and cleanse it using sage, palo santo (a medicinal wood) or a crystal-infused oil spray. I set up my desk with whatever cards and crystals I'm using that day, and then I do a meditation in order to be as grounded as possible, because often a lot of heavy emotional stuff will come up in readings. I need to be sure that I don't take on the emotional energy of others.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2312d45fa9a4767a1daef7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Woods&#39; workspace in the spare room of her house where conducts tarot card readings.\" height=\"480\" width=\"640\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Woods&#39; workspace is in the spare room of her house.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Patti Woods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>I always tell my clients that our reading is their time.&#160;</strong></h2><p>They can ask me questions and tell me as much or as little as they'd like. Some people come with a list of questions and others just want to see what comes up. I shuffle the cards and lay them out and one by one I turn them over.&#160;</p><p>Each card has its own meaning, but the real story happens when you see how the cards interact.&#160;Once some messages start popping up, the client will often start to make the connections and ask deeper questions.&#160;</p><h2>The first two weeks of quarantine, I didn't read for anyone, but then I realized that people needed the cards more than ever.</h2><p>Clients were reaching out to me with questions like, \"Will I get sick?\" \"When will we be done with this?\" and \"I don't even know what to ask right now, I just need something.\"&#160;</p><p>So, I decided to try virtual readings using Zoom and FaceTime. I wasn't sure if this system would work, because a big part of a successful reading is being able to tap into the client's physical energy. Fortunately, it hasn't been an issue at all. Since we've all had to adapt to a new screen-centered lifestyle, I think the technology doesn't present as much of a psychological hurdle as it would have in the past.&#160;</p><p>Tarot readings have always been popular because people have a need for something less clinical (and cheaper) than therapy, and more objective than just talking to friends. A tarot reading offers a safe space for clients to explore their thoughts and feelings and hopefully gain a little insight.&#160;</p><h2><strong>There is no typical client — I've read for kids and grandparents, doctors and lawyers, stay-at-home moms and people who are unemployed.</strong></h2><p><strong><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2315a9a6f0e179ef56a73d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Patti Woods The various tools (sage, palo santo, sprays, selenite) that I use to cleanse my decks and space\" height=\"429\" width=\"640\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The various tools (sage, palo santo, sprays, selenite) that Woods uses to cleanse her decks and meeting space.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Patti Woods</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></strong></p><p>My clients include those who are completely open to the metaphysical and those who are 100% skeptical. I appreciate their willingness to trust me with their story. I see about 10 people a week for private readings, and try to limit myself to two a day, because the sessions can often bear a heavy energy and I want to be as present as possible for each client.</p><p>I also started doing fun, more casual readings once a week on Facebook just to give the cards a chance to breathe. I know how that sounds, but the cards can get weighed down, too. I still have quite a few regular clients that I hear from on a monthly basis. I love getting feedback from people to see how their readings manifested into their lives.&#160;</p><h2>There are a few main questions I always get from clients.</h2><p>People want to know if they'll ever find love, if their family members are okay, and what their job situation looks like. I think the hardest part of reading for me is when someone comes wanting a definitive answer, when they ask questions like, \"Will I get back together with my ex?\" of \"Will I land the job?\" or \"When will COVID-19 end?\" I don't give absolute, set-in-stone answers, because we all have free will and the ability to change our situations at a moment's notice. I always say to look to the cards for guidance, not answers. My job is to present the options and explore the potential results. The best readings start with the question, \"What do I need to know about you and your current situation?\"&#160;</p><p>My ultimate goal with every reading is to make sure the client feels some sense of hope, purpose, or some clarity. The cards may not necessarily say what they want to hear, but at least they can leave with a plan or a direction.&#160;</p><p><em>Patti Woods is a tarot reader and freelance writer based in Trumbull, Connecticut. Visit her <a href=\"https://www.sandyhollowtarot.com/\">website</a>, and join her for frequent live readings on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/groups/boozytarot\">Facebook</a>.</em></p><div (Patti Woods)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f245bfb28ea712ca91a4979?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn20@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-00-021_984c64ecfd6dc469.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f2318aba6f0e17b1873cac5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn71@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-26-973_4e471772d3c38be5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f231268f0f419017c251034?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn35@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-28-813_002f9ccfe78716f3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f2312d45fa9a4767a1daef7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_2/2020/10/17/02-30-23-700_fe02be917d9a3c3d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f2315a9a6f0e179ef56a73d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn36@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-592_ea1566a5c66b9bc3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_6/2020/10/17/02-30-26-160_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fcfyBJDGLDs:C1K-woTVnC4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn76@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-26-873_a0d46c88bde6d308.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fcfyBJDGLDs:C1K-woTVnC4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn51@2020_4/2020/10/17/02-30-15-018_9ca8868d63252ea5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn51@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-21-755_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fcfyBJDGLDs:C1K-woTVnC4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn59@2020_3/2020/10/17/02-30-26-004_47b0ee4d66c496df.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/fcfyBJDGLDs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn28@2020_5/2020/10/17/02-30-25-819_af57877f6eb1feb5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1602901799719},{"createdTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","updatedTime":"2020-10-17 10:29:59","title":"How to cast a Google Meet video call from your computer to a TV screen","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-cast-google-meet-video","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f875355ea23a5001903d699?format=jpeg\" alt=\"conference call video on TV woman blowing out candles\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>If you have casting capability, you can view a Google Meeting on your TV screen.\n<p class=\"copyright\">FilippoBacci/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can cast a Google Meet video call from your computer to your TV if you have a Chromecast or Nest device.</li>\n<li>You can start casting a Google Meeting to your TV before or during the meeting itself.</li>\n<li>When casting, your TV will display the video for the Google Meeting, but you'll still be communicating through your computer's webcam and microphone.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\"><strong>Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>Did you know that you can cast your <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/google-meet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Google Meet</a> video call to your TV?&#160;</p><p>All you need is a computer, a TV, and a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/chromecast\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chromecast</a> or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/nest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nest</a> device set up with casting enabled.&#160;</p><p>Here's how to cast your Google Meet video.</p><h2><strong>How to cast your Google Meet video before you've joined the meeting</strong></h2><p><strong>1.</strong> From the \"waiting room\" area, before you've joined the Google Meeting, click on \"Cast this meeting,\" which is located underneath the \"Join now\" and \"Present\" buttons.</p><ul><li>If this option does not appear, check to make sure your <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fgoogle-chromecast-streaming-media-player-charcoal%2F6288362.p%3FskuId%3D6288362\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Chromecast</a> or <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fnest-hub-max-10-smart-display-with-google-assistant-charcoal%2F6348562.p%3FskuId%3D6348562\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Nest</a> device is working properly and paired with your computer.</li></ul><p><strong>2.</strong> A pop-up will appear in the upper right corner of your web browser, showing a list of all available casting devices. In the pop-up, click on the device you wish to cast to.</p><ul><li>If the device doesn't appear or lists a message saying \"Source not supported,\" double-check that your <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fgoogle-chromecast-streaming-media-player-charcoal%2F6288362.p%3FskuId%3D6288362\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Chromecast</a> or <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fnest-hub-max-10-smart-display-with-google-assistant-charcoal%2F6348562.p%3FskuId%3D6348562\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Nest</a> device is working properly and is set up for casting to the device you wish to cast to.</li></ul><h2><strong>How to cast your Google Meet video while already in a Google Meeting</strong></h2><p><strong>1.</strong> In the bottom right corner of your computer screen, click on the three vertical dots to open a menu.</p><p><strong>2.</strong> In the menu that appears, click on \"Cast this meeting.\"</p><p><strong>3.</strong> A pop-up will appear in the upper right corner of your web browser, showing a list of all available casting devices. In the pop-up, click on the device you wish to cast to.</p><ul><li>Again, if the device doesn't appear, or if you see a message saying \"Source not supported,\" check that your <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fgoogle-chromecast-streaming-media-player-charcoal%2F6288362.p%3FskuId%3D6288362\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Chromecast</a> or <a href=\"https://bestbuy.7tiv.net/c/196318/614286/10014?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bestbuy.com%2Fsite%2Fnest-hub-max-10-smart-display-with-google-assistant-charcoal%2F6348562.p%3FskuId%3D6348562\" rel=\"nofollow sponsored\">Nest</a> device is working and set up for casting to the device in question.</li></ul><p>Now you can join your Google Meeting and view its video on your TV. Keep in mind that you'll still be using your computer to project your own video and audio – only your display will shift to the TV.</p><p>To stop casting your Google Meeting, click on the three vertical dots in the bottom right corner of your screen, then click \"Stop casting meeting\" in the menu that appears.</p><div id=\"ProductCard_5ddd98cdfd9db208c54a43a7\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5ddd98cdfd9db208c54a43a7&type=small&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><div id=\"ProductCard_5e84ecd40c2a6232747e0bb4\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5e84ecd40c2a6232747e0bb4&type=small&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"
